awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the epoch of early galaxy formation is a key objective of astronomy in the coming decade.  This distant, early phase of the Universe is revealed by radio-wave emissions from hydrogen atoms.  Detecting such emission is the goal of radio interferometer arrays.  This project is an innovative method of calibrating one such experiment.  Jacobs and collaborators will use a remote controlled drone octocopter to fly a calibration source over the array and directly measure its response.  Preliminary results demonstrate that this approach is superior to more established methods.  However, drone calibration has not yet been proven for entire arrays.  This project is notable for student participation and the popularity that drone flights achieve in the public imagination.  It will set a new and inexpensive standard for array calibration.  This use of drones captivates students and the general public at outreach events and sets an example of the careful, methodical process of scientific investigation.

This project supports the broad objective of understanding early galaxy formation by detecting redshifted 21cm hydrogen emission using radio telescope arrays.  The Hydrogen Epoch of Reionization Array (HERA), supported by NSF in the Mid-Scale Innovations Program, is one such initiative.  This project seeks to directly map the primary beams of HERA using a calibrated transmitter mounted to a computer controlled drone octocopter.  Drone-based calibration of radio telescopes is gaining popularity, but the method is still experimental.  This project is an outgrowth of a previous, successful award that demonstrated drone-based beam mapping at the Green Bank Observatory.  Results of that work demonstrated comparable accuracy and superior beam coverage to other calibration methods.  This project will extend the methodology previously done on a single antenna to an entire array.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project is to develop the technique of using drone-mounted radio transmitters as calibration sources for radio telescopes. The primary reason for doing this is mitigating systematic limits to 21cm cosmology instruments. These instruments are attempting to observe relic hydrogen during formation of the first stars and galaxies. One of the most notable limitations is knowledge of the antenna response pattern, which this instrument measures.  The technology is also useful generally to radio telescopes, radars, and high energy astrophysics experiments as well as commercial applications.

 

The External Calibrator for Hydrogen Observatories (ECHO) is a concerted effort to advance the technology of drone-based calibration, build an open source platform usable by observatories around the world, and significantly reduce a one of the biggest limitations to 21cm cosmology experiments.

 

Prior to this project, drone-based transmitters had been demonstrated to reach close to the precision required for 21cm applications and several improvements were identified to reach the desired precision. Under this recent project the drone-system was re-designed to improve stability and reduce total cost. Several drone systems were investigated as well as other technologies like tethered balloons and rigid airships. In the end, a custom drone was found to be the best way to meet requirements.

 

The resulting system was tested at several radio telescopes which led to further revisions. In the final testing sequence the demonstrated level of precision was better than required in all measurements. Based on this testing record a set of requirements were devised which can be used as a starting point to design a drone platform with available parts.  The project is published as an open source repository which includes software, hardware designs, and a project memo log.  Memos cover topics like requirements, product evaluations, build logs, and flight reports.  A group of researchers representing several instruments attempting this method meets monthly to compare notes. 

 

The project is driven by the work of undergraduate students and people early in their careers who carried out most aspects of drone design, construction, and field work.  Some 15 students have participated through the lifetime of the project. Many were underrepresented in science and engineering or in other ways non-traditional have gone on to jobs in academia and industries. The most common industry is aerospace.

 

More about 21cm Cosmology:

In the earliest half billion years of cosmic time the first stars and galaxies formed in a process that is not quite explainable by the known laws of nature and difficult to observe. During this time intergalactic hydrogen, observable via 21cm radio emission redshifted by cosmological expansion to meter wavelengths, could open a new window on this process. Instruments probing this epoch are limited by their ability to isolate the distant background from bright foregrounds. Under ideal instrumental conditions foregrounds are distinct from the targeted backgrounds but errors in calibration cause these foregrounds to take on the characteristics associated with the backgrounds. Calibration errors arising in the radio signal chain electronics and the digital signal processing steps can be measured using other methods but errors in the antenna response can only be measured using external sources.
